sn5.10:1.2: Then the nun Vajirā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn5.10:1.3: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Dark Forest,
sn5.10:1.4: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
sn5.10:1.5: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Vajirā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:
sn5.10:3.2: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
sn5.10:3.4: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
sn5.10:3.5: Then Vajirā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn5.10:4.1: “Why do you believe there’s such a thing as a ‘sentient being’?
sn5.10:4.3: This is just a pile of conditions,
sn5.10:4.4: you won’t find a sentient being here.
sn5.10:5.3: So too, when the aggregates are present
sn5.10:5.4: ‘sentient being’ is the convention we use.
sn5.10:6.1: But it’s only suffering that comes to be,
sn5.10:6.3: Naught but suffering comes to be,
sn5.10:7.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Vajirā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
sn5.10:8.6: The Linked Discourses on Nuns are completed.
